items.title: Transforming climate services with LLMs and multi-source data integration
items.body:
Download PDF

Article
    
        
            Open access

Published: 25 October 2025

Transforming climate services with LLMs and multi-source data integration
                    Ivan Kuznetsov1, Antonia Anna Jost1, Dmitrii Pantiukhin1, Boris Shapkin1, Thomas Jung1,2 & …Nikolay Koldunov1 Show authors

npj Climate Action

volume 4, Article number: 97 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate change

AbstractIntegrating Large Language Models (LLMs) with climate model data, scientific literature, and unstructured text enables a new generation of climate information systems that deliver accurate, localized, and context-aware insights. Our primary objective is to develop and evaluate ClimSight, a scalable platform that turns complex heterogeneous data into actionable information. We augment LLMs with Retrieval Augmented Generation, a method that retrieves relevant climate models and reports at query time to ground responses. An agent-based architecture orchestrates specialized modules that route and process user queries with task-specific tools. Real-world evaluations compare multiple LLM configurations and analyze trade-offs between speed, cost, and accuracy. Results show improved scalability and precision in climate assessments, democratizing access to localized information. This paradigm shift equips stakeholders in agriculture, urban planning, disaster management, and policy with effective tools for forward planning and risk management.

IntroductionClimate change is increasingly affecting societies worldwide, leading to a growing need for accurate and localized climate assessments. Traditional climate information systems often struggle to provide tailored insights due to limitations in data granularity, interpretability, and contextual relevance. Moreover, the widespread impacts of climate change mean that people across the globe are facing more climate-related questions regarding future planning - ranging from agricultural decisions to urban infrastructure adaptation. This demand necessitates scalable solutions capable of addressing climate-related inquiries at both local and global levels.Recent advances in artificial intelligence, particularly in Large Language Models (LLMs), have opened new possibilities for enhancing climate services. LLMs, like those developed by OpenAI and others1,2,3, are capable of understanding complex language patterns, synthesizing information from diverse sources, and generating human-like text. However, standard LLMs face significant challenges when interpreting specialized climate data, mainly due to their general-purpose design and lack of domain-specific training4. Several AI-driven climate information platforms have emerged in recent years. For example, ChatClimate5 grounds a GPT-4 model’s responses in the IPCC Sixth Assessment Report to ensure up-to-date, scientifically accurate answers, and ClimateQ&A6 leverages an LLM with a knowledge base from IPCC/IPBES reports. Other efforts include ClimateGPT7, which uses climate-specific LLMs trained on interdisciplinary literature, and ChatNetZero8, a retrieval-augmented chatbot for climate pledges. Additionally, The Climate Explorer9, while not AI-based, provides tools and information to help build climate resilience. These systems represent important advances in climate information delivery, yet they often rely on specific document corpora or narrow use cases, which hinder their ability to provide accurate, context-aware climate assessments at scale.To meet these challenges, there is a pressing need for climate information systems that are not only accurate and localized but also scalable to address the increasing volume of climate-related questions worldwide. ClimSight10 aims to bridge this gap by leveraging advanced LLMs and integrating diverse data sources, including unstructured text and domain-specific databases, ensuring comprehensive, context-aware, and scalable climate assessments.ClimSight integrates advanced LLMs with high-resolution geographical and climate data, providing localized climate insights tailored to specific user needs and activities. The system leverages Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) techniques11,12 and an agent-based architecture13,14,15 to overcome the limitations of general-purpose models. By incorporating domain-specific knowledge and high-resolution spatial data16,17,18, ClimSight delivers accurate, reliable, and reproducible climate assessments at a granular, location-specific level.The developed approach distinguishes itself from existing climate information systems through several key advancements:
                
                  Integration of LLMs: The proposed methodology leverages state-of-the-art LLMs to interpret complex climate-related queries, synthesizing information from diverse data sources, including scientific reports, IPCC documents, and geographical databases. This allows the system to provide nuanced, context-aware insights that go beyond traditional numerical models.
                
                
                  Multi-Source Data Integration: Unlike conventional systems that rely solely on structured climate data, our platform integrates information from multiple sources, including unstructured text, domain-specific literature, and online databases. This approach ensures comprehensive climate assessments tailored to specific user needs.
                
                
                  RAG System: ClimSight enhances LLMs’ contextual understanding by retrieving relevant knowledge from external sources, ensuring evidence-based and contextually accurate answers. This approach bridges the gap between static datasets and dynamic, context-aware insights.
                
                
                  Agent-Based Architecture: By employing a modular, agent-based design, the framework ensures scalability, flexibility, and improved system efficiency. Specialized agents handle distinct tasks, such as data retrieval, contextual understanding, and result synthesis, leading to more accurate and coherent outputs.
                
                
                  Practical Use Cases and Real-World Applications: The solution is validated through practical examples, such as assessing climate risks for specific agricultural activities and urban planning scenarios. These use cases demonstrate its potential to support climate-informed decision-making across various sectors.
                
              The target audience includes researchers, providers of climate services, policymakers, agricultural planners, urban developers, and other stakeholders who require detailed climate information. ClimSight is designed to democratize access to climate data, empowering users with actionable insights relevant to their specific contexts.This paper provides a comprehensive overview of the system’s architecture, methodologies, and evaluation framework. It demonstrates the platforms’s effectiveness through real-world examples and comparative analyses, highlighting its contribution to climate services. By addressing the limitations of traditional systems and leveraging state-of-the-art AI techniques, ClimSight contributes to the evolving landscape of digital climate twins and next-generation climate information systems.ResultsThis section presents the performance outcomes of ClimSight, including usage examples with two distinct models and their corresponding visualizations.As an example of the concept’s capabilities, we tested its response to a question previously explored in ref. 10: “What are the potential risks and benefits of climate change for growing wheat?” at a location in Morocco (31.6912N, 8.1098W). The answer was generated using GPT-4o and is shown in Box 1. To illustrate how the response was created, Fig. 1 presents a visual representation of the process. This diagram shows the different steps involved, including retrieving relevant information, formatting the data, and reasoning through the response. The process relies on several specialized components, each performing a specific role (In parentheses, the names of the components are indicated in Fig. 1):
                
                  Location Requests (not in LangGraph):
                  Retrieves addresses and land/water status from coordinates
                
                
                  Doorman (intro_agent):
                  Introductory interface of the system
                
                
                  API & Local Data Requests (zero_rag_agent):
                  Retrieves location-specific data from various datasets.
                
                
                  IPCC (ipcc_rag_agent):
                  Retrieves climate-related information from IPCC reports.
                
                
                  Reports (general_rag_agent):
                  Pulls additional context from broader climate literature.
                
                
                  Climate model data (data_agent):
                  Derive data from climate models output
                
                
                  Smart agent (smart_agent):
                  Retrieve and synthesize information from multiple heterogeneous data sources.
                
                
                  Combine (combine_agent):
                  Synthesizes information to generate a well-structured response.
                
              Fig. 1: ClimSight LangGraph query.Visualization of a LangGraph schema for a question about wheat near by Marrakech using GPT-4o (a) and o1-preview (b).Full size imageThese components operate partly sequentially and partly in parallel, processing the request in 41.25 seconds at a cost of about 8 cents, handling approximately 28,000 tokens (units of text processed by the AI). To compare performance, we repeated the same query but used a different model, o1-preview, for the final step (Box 2). This adjustment significantly increased the response time to 74 seconds, mainly because the final processing step took 46 seconds instead of 14 seconds. The cost also rose to 39 cents.Both answers use the same input climate model data and basic information but differ in depth and detail. Answer 1 (gpt-4o) provides a concise evaluation, focusing mainly on temperature increases, precipitation deficits, and flood risks, with only brief mentions of adaptation strategies. It emphasizes the direct impact of temperature and moisture on wheat without addressing broader factors like pests or soil degradation. In contrast, Answer 2 (o1-preview) offers a more comprehensive analysis, incorporating decade-specific climate projections and detailed risk factors, such as increased pest pressure and soil degradation, as well as specific adaptation strategies like drought-tolerant varieties and efficient irrigation methods. Answer 2 also includes additional contextual information, such as the region’s soil type and land use, providing a broader perspective on the challenges and opportunities for wheat cultivation. Overall, Answer 2 is more thorough, offering a fuller picture of potential climate change impacts and adaptive responses for wheat farming in this region.Despite differences in responses caused by using different models - referred to here as 4o and o1 - in the final step, the answers are fundamentally similar. The similarity comes from the nearly identical input data. However, since data from the database is first processed by the LLM before reaching ‘Combine‘, variations arise in the input to ‘Combine‘. The analysis potential of model o1 is greater. However, using model o1 requires more financial resources and time. It can be concluded that model o1 is justified for final decision-making. For quick queries, model 4o is sufficient. It provides a preliminary impression and a first approximation.We also conducted experiments with an open Gemma 7B model12. This model was significantly reduced to 7 billion parameters. Such a size makes it usable on a personal laptop. However, in our tests, the results were considerably more modest compared to those of model 4o. However, using such small models can be justified in intermediate steps. This approach significantly speeds up queries and reduces costs.In the current version, we used high-resolution data averaged for the 2020s, compared to the previous version10, which relied on lower-resolution CMIP6 simulations. While absolute temperature and precipitation values differ slightly between the versions, both indicate significantly higher temperatures than the critical thresholds for wheat growth. In the older version, these thresholds were derived from pre-trained datasets, whereas the newer version employs precise values from the ECOCROP database19, enhancing accuracy. Furthermore, the updated analysis focuses on short-term climate impacts (2020-2049), in contrast to the longer-term period (2070-2100) considered previously, resulting in a more actionable timeframe. The newer version also introduces additional plots to visualize the data, providing clearer insights into key climate trends. Finally, the updated analysis integrates nuanced risk factors, such as increases in wind speed, and aligns with Morocco’s climate adaptation policies, presenting a more comprehensive and practical assessment. A “References” tab was introduced, allowing users to trace the sources of information utilized in generating the report.Box 1 ClimSight with gpt-4o: question about wheat near by MarrakechThe potential risks and benefits of growing wheat in Saâda, Morocco, under the influence of climate change can be evaluated with regard to the prevailing and projected climatic and environmental conditions.Risks:
                  
                    1.
                    
                      Temperature Increases: The data indicates a significant rise in temperatures over the decades. For instance, the average temperature in August is projected to rise from 35.11 °C in the 2020s to 36.77 °C in the 2040s. Such temperatures exceed the optimal range for wheat (15 °C to 23 °C) and approach the absolute maximum temperature threshold of 27 °C for wheat cultivation. This increase can lead to heat stress, negatively impacting wheat yields during critical growth phases.
                    
                  
                  
                    2.
                    
                      Precipitation Deficits: The annual precipitation levels are well below the optimal requirement for wheat, which ranges from 750 mm to 900 mm. The highest monthly precipitation is expected to be just 10.05 mm in December by the 2040s, indicating a severe shortfall and potential for drought stress. Wheat requires consistent moisture, especially during germination and early growth stages, which this region may not be able to provide without substantial irrigation.
                    
                  
                  
                    3.
                    
                      Flood Risks: Historical data shows that the region has experienced floods (in 1995, 1996, 1997, and 2008), which could pose additional risks such as soil erosion or waterlogged conditions that are detrimental to wheat.
                    
                  
                Benefits:
                  
                    1.
                    
                      Extended Growing Season: The rise in temperatures might allow for a longer growing season, which could be beneficial if managed correctly with appropriate wheat varieties that are heat-tolerant and have shorter growing cycles.
                    
                  
                  
                    2.
                    
                      CO2 Fertilization Effect: Increased atmospheric CO2 levels can enhance photosynthesis in C3 plants like wheat, potentially offsetting some yield losses due to heat stress. However, this benefit is contingent upon sufficient water availability, which remains a significant constraint in this region.
                    
                  
                  
                    3.
                    
                      Increased Wind Speed: With slight increases in wind speeds over the years, although generally not beneficial for wheat pollination (as it is predominantly self-pollinating), it may aid in reducing humidity and preventing certain fungal diseases that thrive in stagnant, moist air conditions.
                    
                  
                In summary, while the projected climatic changes in Saâda, Morocco, present several risks to wheat cultivation, particularly concerning temperature increases and inadequate precipitation, there are potential benefits that could be exploited with careful management. Adaptation strategies such as selecting heat-tolerant wheat varieties, improving irrigation infrastructure, and implementing soil moisture conservation practices will be crucial to mitigating the adverse effects of climate change on wheat production in this region.Box 2 ClimSight with o1-preview: question about wheat near by MarrakechClimate change is poised to significantly impact the cultivation of wheat in Saâda, Morocco (latitude 31.6912, longitude -8.1098). Situated at an elevation of 384 meters above sea level with Luvisols soil - known for their fertility and suitability for agriculture - the region currently utilizes its land primarily for orchards. However, the prospect of growing wheat here faces both challenges and opportunities due to shifting climatic conditions.Temperature trends and ImplicationsAtmospheric model simulations indicate a clear upward trend in temperatures for Saâda:
                  
                    2020–2029: Monthly average temperatures range from 8.36 °C in January to 35.11 °C in August.
                  
                  
                    2030–2039: Temperatures rise slightly, with January averaging 8.76 °C and August 36.12 °C.
                  
                  
                    2040–2049: Further increases project January at 9.41 °C and August at 36.77 °C.
                  
                Wheat thrives in optimal temperatures between 15 °C and 23 °C (ECOCROP database). Temperatures above 27 °C approach the absolute maximum for wheat growth. The projected increases, particularly in the hottest months, suggest that wheat crops may experience heat stress, especially during critical growth periods like grain filling. Elevated temperatures can accelerate plant development unnaturally, reducing the time for grain maturation and potentially leading to lower yields.Precipitation patterns and water availabilityThe region’s precipitation is notably low and is expected to fluctuate:
                  
                    2020–2029: Total monthly precipitation varies from 0.33 mm in August to 8.4 mm in February.
                  
                  
                    2030–2039: A significant decrease is projected in February, dropping to 2.66 mm.
                  
                  
                    2040–2049: February precipitation further declines to a mere 0.16 mm, while December sees an increase to 10.05 mm.
                  
                Wheat requires annual rainfall between 750 mm and 900 mm for optimal growth (ECOCROP database). The current and projected precipitation levels in Saâda are well below these requirements. This substantial deficit indicates a high risk of drought stress, making wheat cultivation heavily reliant on irrigation. Moreover, decreasing rainfall during crucial planting seasons could exacerbate water scarcity, increasing the dependency on irrigation systems and elevating production costs.Potential Risks
                  
                    1.
                    
                      Heat stress on Crops: Rising temperatures may surpass wheat’s tolerable limits, especially during summer, affecting photosynthesis and leading to reduced grain quality and yields.
                    
                  
                  
                    2.
                    
                      Water Scarcity: Lower precipitation combined with higher evaporation rates can diminish water availability, stressing both rainfed and irrigated wheat systems.
                    
                  
                  
                    3.
                    
                      Increased Pest and Disease Pressure: Warmer temperatures may alter the lifecycle and prevalence of pests and diseases harmful to wheat, potentially increasing infestation risks.
                    
                  
                  
                    4.
                    
                      Extreme Weather Events: Although the historical data mentions floods in 1995, 1996, 1997, and 2008, climate change could lead to more frequent and severe events, threatening crop stability.
                    
                  
                  
                    5.
                    
                      Soil Degradation: Higher temperatures and erratic rainfall can lead to soil moisture depletion, affecting nutrient uptake and soil structure.
                    
                  
                Potential Benefits
                  
                    1.
                    
                      CO2 Fertilization Effect: Elevated atmospheric CO2 levels can enhance photosynthesis in C3 plants like wheat, potentially improving biomass and grain yields. However, this benefit may be limited by nutrient and water availability.
                    
                  
                  
                    2.
                    
                      Extended Growing Seasons: Warmer temperatures might allow for longer growing seasons or the possibility of double cropping, provided that water resources are sufficient.
                    
                  
                Adaptation StrategiesTo navigate these challenges and harness potential benefits, several strategies can be employed:
                  
                    Drought-Tolerant Varieties: Developing or adopting wheat varieties bred for heat and drought tolerance can mitigate some of the adverse effects.
                  
                  
                    Efficient Irrigation Techniques: Implementing water-saving irrigation methods such as drip irrigation can optimize water use and reduce wastage.
                  
                  
                    Soil Conservation Practices: Techniques like mulching, cover cropping, and conservation tillage can improve soil moisture retention and reduce erosion.
                  
                  
                    Adjusted Planting Schedules: Shifting planting dates to cooler periods can help avoid peak temperature stresses.
                  
                  
                    Integrated Pest Management: Monitoring and controlling pest populations proactively can reduce the risk of infestations exacerbated by climate change.
                  
                ConclusionThe cultivation of wheat in Saâda, Morocco, faces considerable risks due to climate change, primarily from increasing temperatures and decreasing precipitation during key growth periods. These factors threaten to exacerbate heat and drought stresses, potentially leading to reduced yields and increased reliance on irrigation.While there are potential benefits such as the CO2 fertilization effect and possibly extended growing seasons, these are contingent upon effective management of water resources and other agronomic practices. Proactive adaptation strategies are essential to mitigate risks and sustain wheat production in this region.References
                  
                    ECOCROP Database: Provides essential crop requirements, indicating optimal temperatures of 15 °C to 23 °C and annual rainfall needs of 750 mm to 900 mm for wheat.
                  
                  
                    Atmospheric Model Simulations (2020-2049): Projected climate data for Saâda, showing increases in average temperatures and fluctuations in precipitation.
                  
                  
                    Smart Data Extractor Agent Analysis: Highlights the discrepancies between wheat’s requirements and the projected climatic conditions in Saâda.
                  
                DiscussionThe proposed framework demonstrates significant potential in providing accurate and localized climate insights by integrating Large Language Models (LLMs) with diverse data sources, including text, scientific literature, and climate data. The results highlight ClimSight’s capability to synthesize complex information into actionable, context-aware assessments. This is particularly relevant for decision-makers in sectors such as agriculture, urban planning, and disaster management, where localized climate information is crucial for informed planning and risk management. We acknowledge that our study presents a conceptual framework at this stage and requires comprehensive validation through user studies, particularly given the involvement of large language models in generating climate assessments.The evaluation shows that the developed approach enhances the precision and relevance of climate assessments while maintaining scalability, enabling it to address the growing volume of climate-related questions worldwide. By leveraging Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) and an agent-based architecture, this methodology effectively overcomes the limitations of traditional climate information systems, providing a more nuanced understanding of localized climate impacts. However, the evaluation dataset currently consists of only 30 QA pairs, primarily used for initial system tuning. Future work will expand this dataset to several thousand QA pairs, enabling more comprehensive system evaluation and supporting the fine-tuning of open-source models. However, the current evaluation relies solely on LLM-based scoring, which, while scalable, lacks external expert validation. This may limit the robustness of the conclusions, especially in high-stakes or policy-relevant contexts. To address this, future work will incorporate expert reviews, structured usability studies, and domain-specific user feedback to assess ClimSight’s outputs. Particular attention will be given to collecting targeted evaluations from users in agriculture, urban planning, and policy sectors to guide iterative improvements and validate system credibility. Implementing these stakeholder-driven studies will require a dedicated mixed-methods effort that lies beyond the present project’s resources, so this paper intentionally confines itself to an automated, scalable evaluation as a transparent baseline for future user-centered validation.While this version focuses on demonstrating a scalable automated assessment pipeline, we acknowledge the need for more rigorous empirical grounding. This includes future integration of observational data and probabilistic climate model ensembles to capture uncertainty, as well as broader real-world use cases beyond those presented here.A key strength of the proposed framework lies in its integration of LLMs with multiple data sources, including unstructured text, which allows for a holistic view of climate information. This approach enables the platform to contextualize data according to specific user needs, enhancing the relevance and usability of the outputs. The agent-based architecture further contributes to system efficiency and scalability, ensuring flexible integration of future data sources and model updates.However, the implemented methodology also faces limitations, particularly in its dependency on external APIs and data availability. The quality and reliability of outputs are influenced by the accuracy of input data and the limitations of LLMs, including their sensitivity to prompt design and potential biases. These potential biases include hallucinations, where the LLM generates plausible but incorrect information not derived from the provided data, and instances where numerical values are drawn from the model’s internal parameters rather than validated external datasets. Additionally, integrating unstructured text and diverse data sources introduces challenges in maintaining consistency and verifiability of the assessments. Moreover, the current implementation presents climate model data without explicit uncertainty quantification. Further development should also focus on incorporating explicit uncertainty quantifications, confidence intervals for projected climate trends, and recalculated biases from climate models to enhance the interpretability and reliability of ClimSight outputs.Traditional systems typically rely on static datasets and numerical models with limited contextual adaptation. In contrast, ClimSight dynamically retrieves and synthesizes relevant information, offering evidence-based insights tailored to user-specific queries. Compared to other AI-driven climate platforms, the agent-based architecture enhances modularity and flexibility, allowing for targeted data retrieval and contextual understanding. This modular approach not only optimizes performance but also enables the system to adapt to rapidly evolving climate science and user needs.The growing impacts of climate change globally necessitate scalable climate information systems capable of addressing diverse, localized questions. The presented concept contributes to this need by democratizing access to localized climate information, empowering stakeholders ranging from researchers and policymakers to communities and businesses.Future developments will focus on enhancing real-time data integration and expanding the application of this approach across different climate-sensitive sectors. Additionally, refining the evaluation framework to include cross-validation with observed data will improve the reliability and consistency of the assessments. Efforts to minimize risks associated with false information will include developing additional verification mechanisms. For instance, agent prompts will explicitly highlight discrepancies when different datasets provide contradictory information. Additionally, future plans involve creating ”second-eye” agents to double-check statistical calculations performed by ClimSight and dedicated fact-checking agents to further reduce misinformation risks. Integrating more advanced LLMs and expanding the diversity of data sources, including social and economic data, will further enhance the system’s contextual awareness and usability.The current reliance on the OpenAI API poses potential cost challenges with increased usage. Nevertheless, rapid advancements in LLM technologies are continuously reducing these costs. For example, in 2024-2025, GPT-4o usage costs decreased significantly, and the introduction of GPT-4.1 Nano further reduced query expenses to a fraction of the earlier costs. ClimSight’s flexible architecture, built upon the LangChain framework, allows seamless integration and switching between various LLMs, including open-source alternatives capable of running locally. Future research and development efforts will prioritize extending support for these open-source models, which will further mitigate costs and enhance the scalability and accessibility of the platform.This novel methodology represents a paradigm shift in how climate data is synthesized and utilized, bridging the gap between scientific complexity and practical decision making. As climate change continues to present complex challenges, scalable and adaptable solutions like the proposed system are essential for supporting informed future planning and effective risk management.MethodsThis section outlines the methodology and system architecture behind ClimSight. Additionally, the evaluation subsection provides a comparative analysis of the system’s responses across multiple queries, supported by relevant statistical data.ClimSight: concept and architectureClimSight leverages LLMs to generate climate assessments tailored to user-defined locations and activities. The initial concept, introduced by10, demonstrated that supplementing LLM prompts with localized climate data improves the accuracy and relevance of climate information. In this work, we extend this approach by integrating additional environmental datasets, high-resolution climate model outputs, and contextual knowledge from climate reports and scientific literature.To manage the increasing data volume and complexity, ClimSight now follows a modular architecture, with specialized components handling specific tasks (Fig. 2). The system follows these key steps:Fig. 2: ClimSight schematic.Dashed lines indicate conditional calls. Solid arrows represent the mandatory path from one agent to another. Numbers show the key steps mentioned in the section “ClimSight: Concept and Architecture”.Full size image
                  
                    1.
                    
                      User Input—The user provides a question and geographic coordinates.
                    
                  
                  
                    2.
                    
                      Location Processing—ClimSight determines the location details and contextual information.
                    
                  
                  
                    3.
                    
                      Data Retrieval—The system queries online and pre-downloaded climate databases, extracts relevant climate model outputs, and retrieves climate reports.
                    
                  
                  
                    4.
                    
                      Smart Analysis—A specialized agent interprets data based on the user’s request (e.g., applying climate thresholds relevant to a specific crop).
                    
                  
                  
                    5.
                    
                      Information Filtering—The LLM processes and refines relevant content from databases and reports.
                    
                  
                  
                    6.
                    
                      Final Report Generation—A ”combine agent” synthesizes findings into a user-friendly climate impact assessment.
                    
                  
                To evaluate the system’s reliability, ClimSight includes an evaluation module that systematically assesses the quality of its responses (see Evaluation section). ClimSight is primarily developed in Python, with a Streamlit-based web interface and a command-line version. It uses LangChain and LangGraph frameworks20 for managing agent interactions and LLM calls. The modular design enables easy integration of different LLMs, and while OpenAI models are currently used, preliminary tests have been conducted with the open-source Gemma 7B model. The system’s modularity allows seamless adaptation to different applications and continuous updates through a CI pipeline. ClimSight is open-source (BSD 3-Clause License) and available for public use, modification, and expansion. Below, we describe the core components in more detail.Core componentsUser inputThe user submits a question along with geographic coordinates (longitude and latitude).Location requestsThis module determines the location’s address (via the Nominatim API21) and whether it is on land or water (using Natural Earth datasets22).Query filteringThe ”Doorman” serves as an initial filter, evaluating whether the user’s query is relevant to climate-informed decision-making. If so, it extracts preliminary contextual information before passing the request to specialized components.Data retrievalClimSight collects location-specific environmental and climate information from multiple sources:
                    
                      Natural hazards - EM-DAT / GDIS datasets (1960-2018)23,24
                    
                    
                      Population data - UN World Population Prospects (2022)25
                    
                    
                      Biodiversity records - GBIF API26
                    
                    
                      Elevation data - Open Topo Data API27,28
                    
                    
                      Land use - Overpass API (OpenStreetMap)29
                    
                    
                      Soil types - ISRIC SoilGrids API30
                    
                    
                      Coastline proximity - Natural Earth datasets22
                    
                  Climate reports and literatureTwo modules provide contextual climate knowledge,
                    
                      1.
                      
                        IPCC Reports Module—Focuses on the IPCC 6th Assessment Report, ensuring high credibility.
                      
                    
                    
                      2.
                      
                        Scientific Reports Module—Includes a broader set of WMO reports, German climate-health reports (RKI), and others.
                      
                    
                  By keeping these databases separate, ClimSight ensures users receive high-quality assessments based on both authoritative global perspectives and localized insights. If no relevant information is found, these sources are omitted from the final output.Climate model data processingClimSight analyzes four primary climate variables: 2m air temperature, precipitation, wind speed, and wind direction. It incorporates:
                    
                      Coarse-resolution climate model data (100 km) from AWI-CM (CMIP6), covering past (1985-2004) and future (2070-2100) climate scenarios.
                    
                    
                      High-resolution simulations from nextGEMS (9 km), coupled with the FESOM ocean model, spanning 2020-204931,32.
                    
                  Smart agent analysisThe Smart agent (Fig. 3) functions as a specialized analytical component that evaluates climate-relevant parameters based on user queries. This LLM-powered component synthesizes information from multiple data sources to provide contextually appropriate climate assessments. The agent operates through four primary information retrieval mechanisms:
                    
                      Encyclopedic Knowledge: Conducts targeted Wikipedia searches to establish baseline environmental parameters and thresholds for specific activities or crops.
                    
                    
                      Scientific Literature Integration: Queries a vector database of agricultural and climate research papers to identify climate sensitivity factors and environmental constraints.
                    
                    
                      Agricultural Requirements Database: For crop-specific queries, consults the ECOCROP database19 to determine optimal growing conditions and climate thresholds.
                    
                    
                      Climate Data Retrieval: Accesses pre-processed climate model outputs for the specified geographical coordinates, extracting temperature, precipitation, and wind parameters relevant to the query.
                    
                  Fig. 3: Smart agent schematic.Dashed lines indicate conditional calls. Solid arrows represent the mandatory path.Full size imageThe agent employs a two-phase workflowfirst determining which environmental parameters are relevant to the user’s query through knowledge base consultation, then retrieving and analyzing the specific climate data for those parameters.Final report generation and accessibilityAfter data retrieval and analysis, ClimSight synthesizes findings into a user-friendly climate assessment report. The system can be accessed via a web browser or terminal, requiring an OpenAI API key for operation. Essential datasets are preloaded, while additional data is fetched dynamically via API requests. This structured approach ensures ClimSight remains flexible, scalable, and accessible for climate-informed decision-making across various applications.EvaluationWe employed a modified version of the evaluation framework proposed by Liu et al.33 to assess the quality of responses generated by ClimSight. This framework adopts a reference-based approach, in which the generated answers are compared against predefined reference answers using LLMs (see Fig. 4). Consistent with33, we incorporated chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning by instructing the LLM to evaluate responses across multiple criteria: Completeness, Accuracy, Relevance, Clarity, and Coherence. Each answer is assigned a score from 1 to 5 for each criterion, and these scores are compiled to produce an overall assessment of response quality. Detailed explanations for each evaluation criterion are provided in the Supplementary Note section “Prompt for evaluation”. Our evaluation prompt guides the LLM through a structured process:
                  
                    Understand the Question Context
                  
                  
                    Analyze the Provided Answers
                  
                  
                    Compare Answers for Completeness
                  
                  
                    Assess Accuracy and Relevance
                  
                  
                    Evaluate Clarity and Coherence
                  
                  
                    Rate the Answer
                  
                  
                    Provide Feedback and Suggestions
                  
                Fig. 4Schematic of the evaluation module.Full size imageBy leveraging LLMs with CoT reasoning, this evaluation framework provides a systematic analysis of ClimSight’s responses. As demonstrated by33, such an approach correlates strongly with human judgments. This evaluator is actively employed in application development to assess modifications including the addition or removal of components, and to identify specific issues related to modernization, such as changes in the sequence of components calls.In the context of evaluating system performance, we used questions derived from IPCC reports to verify the system’s ability to address general inquiries and to test the effectiveness of its RAG. We also compiled a set of 30 question-answer pairs generated by the o1 model using ClimSight, which we verified based on our expertise in climate research and climate assessments. As an example, one of the questions was, “Will expanding wheat fields in this region ensure consistent harvests over the next decade?” supplemented with geographic coordinates in Spain. Questions for evaluation were grouped into several thematic categories: “General Climate Risks,” “Business-Specific Concerns,” “Agriculture and Food Production,” “Renewable Energy and Infrastructure,” “Urban and Community Planning,” “Coastal and Water-Related Risks,” “Community and Ecosystem Impacts,” “Energy and Supply Chain Resilience,” “Industry-Specific Impacts,” and “Long-Term Sustainability.” Within each category, questions were divided into “general” and “specific” types; for example, a general question included “How will climate change impact agricultural yields at this location?” while a specific question was “Can we continue growing grapes at our vineyard located here under future climate scenarios?” The locations associated with each question were randomly selected globally, ensuring each point lies on land. To evaluate how our system’s responses depend on different LLM models, we used ClimSight to answer the same set of questions, while varying the final model.In experiments involving gpt-4o and higher-level models, we employed gpt-4o for textual RAG and changed only the model in the final step “Combine” since the o1 family does not integrate tools well in the current LangChain environment. The comparative results (see Table 1) indicate that using more advanced models for combining information, as expected, yields higher scores. We do not show a direct comparison with o1 itself alone because it tends to self-score at maximum (5), diminishing its utility for direct comparison. The last row in Table 1 (“Pure gpt-4o, no ClimSight”) provides a control experiment in which gpt-4o was used without ClimSight. Although gpt-4o typically recognized the geographic context of a question often pinpointing a city or region its answers lacked the additional data that ClimSight provides. As a result, the overall performance of a pure gpt-4o system approached that of gpt-3.5 paired with ClimSight. Notably, the gpt-4o-only responses often contained vague statements or very broad temperature ranges (e.g., “average temperatures may increase by 1-5 °C”), which offer limited value for a detailed climate assessment.Table 1 Results of the evaluation using different LLM models, with and without ClimSight and the ’smart’ agent, based on 30 pairs of questions and answers, as well as MMLU (Massive Multitask Language Understanding) and GPQA (General-Purpose Question Answering) benchmarksFull size tableBy comparison, simpler based models like Gemma 7B were generally unable to link geographic coordinates to relevant geographic attributes and therefore performed significantly worse in similar tests (results not shown). Furthermore, when we supplemented our system with the “Smart agent”, the average response quality (mean score) increased from 3.475 to 3.76, largely because of improvements in Completeness and Accuracy. This effect was most pronounced in questions related to crops, where the system could leverage information from an ECOCROP database tied to the specific plant in question.In practice, this evaluation methodology helps identify how much the system’s responses improve after modifications, such as adding or removing components, and supports quantitative assessments when the underlying LLM is changed. As shown in Table 1, the o1 models tend to be more computationally expensive and slower compared to gpt-4o. For more efficient deployment, one could use ClimSight with gpt-4o or even gpt-3.5 to handle preliminary inquiries, reserving o1 for final, complex queries where its enhanced capabilities justify the additional cost.In addition, we observe that GPQA (A Graduate-Level Google-Proof Q&A Benchmark) has an exceptionally high correlation with our own evaluation metrics (Table 1), on the order of 0.97, while the correlation with MMLU (Massive Multitask Language Understanding Benchmark) is 0.8. This result seems intuitive when looking at o1-mini and GPT-4o: although o1-mini’s MMLU score (85.2) is slightly lower than GPT-4o’s (88.7), its GPQA score (60.0) exceeds GPT-4o’s (53.6), reflecting o1-mini’s stronger performance on our custom metrics (4.29 vs. 3.76 mean score). In other words, o1-mini appears to offer more robust domain-specific reasoning and completeness, likely due to a more STEM-focused training that better matches the specialized tasks in ClimSight. Given this near-perfect correlation between GPQA and our custom metrics, we consider GPQA a crucial indicator when selecting LLMs for ClimSight.In conclusion, our evaluation framework, adapted from Liu et al.33, demonstrates how integrating ClimSight and specific components can enhance response quality and provide measurable improvements in various criteria. Moreover, these findings clearly illustrate ClimSight’s superiority in handling climate-specific inquiries, as it consistently provides more specialized, accurate and contextual responses than LLMs alone. Including domain specific databases and task-oriented agents, the developed approach delivers deeper insights that are critical for robust climate assessment. Nevertheless, explicitly verifying the accuracy of specific numerical values, such as seasonal mean temperatures or precipitation, remains a challenge that requires additional verification mechanisms, currently under development in an updated version of ClimSight. This approach is particularly valuable during system development, allowing for systematic assessments of how each component contributes to overall performance.

North Atlantic Ocean natural variability drives glacier mass loss over the Northeastern Tibetan Plateau
                    Min Zhou 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-4657-12771, Yetang Wang 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-2499-11471, Shugui Hou 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-0905-35422, Zhaosheng Zhai1, Zhiguo Li3,4, Weijun Sun1 & …Yuzhe Wang1 Show authors

Communications Earth & Environment

volume 6, Article number: 843 (2025)

Subjects
        
            Climate changeCryospheric science

AbstractOcean temperature anomalies can drive anomalous atmospheric circulation, further impacting High Mountain Asia’s glacier dynamics, but this teleconnection remains underexplored. Here we present robust interannual and multidecadal relationships between glacier mass balance over the northeastern Tibetan Plateau and the North Atlantic sea surface temperature anomalies, after removing anthropogenic warming trends. The annual sea surface temperature tripole pattern explains 33.6% of the interannual glacier mass variability, mediated by the atmospheric wave train. On multi-decadal timescales, the average glacier mass loss of the northeastern Tibetan Plateau accelerates from −0.16 ± 0.14 m w.e. yr−1 (1965–2000) to −0.25 ± 0.10 m w.e. yr−1 (2000–2020), coinciding with a phase shift of the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation. Anomalous North Atlantic warming triggers mid-latitude Rossby waves and an anticyclone over the northeastern Tibetan Plateau, amplifying early-21st-century regional warming through reduced clouds and albedo to enhance glacier mass loss. These results emphasize the crucial role of natural variability in the North Atlantic ocean alongside anthropogenic forcing in comprehensively understanding glacier response to future climate changes.

IntroductionThe High Mountain Asia (HMA), excluding the Antarctic and Arctic, hosts the largest fraction of Earth’s glaciers, commonly known as the Asian water tower, because it sustains irrigation, freshwater supplies, and hydropower for nearly two billion people in Asia1,2,3. As a consequence of the approximately two-fold warming faster than the global mean in this region4, the Asian water tower has experienced an imbalance in recent decades5, with the transformation of more and more ice and snow into liquid water. Progressive ice-to-water conversion has triggered frequent occurrences of glacier-associated hazards such as outbursts of glacier lakes, glacial debris flow, and ice avalanches6,7,8, posing severe threats to human lives, water resources, and ecological security in local and downstream communities.HMA glacier changes exhibit obvious spatial heterogeneity, characterized by considerable ice mass loss in the southern Tibetan Plateau (TP) and relatively minor recession and mass loss in the northern sectors during the 21st century9,10,11,12. Specifically, glaciers in the northwestern TP (Karakoram, Pamir, and western Kunlun Mountains), are in balance or even slightly growing called a phenomenon termed the Karakoram anomaly12,13, which lasts for at least three decades. This spatial heterogeneity arises from regional differences in temperature trends and a north-south dipole precipitation pattern (wetter conditions in the north and drier conditions in the south)14,15. Divergent regional climate changes in the HMA are primarily governed by both mid-latitude westerly circulation and Asian summer monsoon, and further modulated by oceanic teleconnection associated with main SST variability modes, including the Atlantic multidecadal oscillation (AMO), the Pacific decadal oscillation (PDO) and the Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD)16,17,18,19. Thus, oceanic teleconnections are likely important contributors to the TP glacier mass changes through modulating atmospheric circulation patterns. Nevertheless, the quantitative relationship between oceanic SST anomalies and regional glacier mass balance remains unclear, and the physical mechanism underlying these teleconnections is not yet fully understood.Here, we test the role of North Atlantic sea surface temperature (NASST) anomalies in glacier mass balance in the northeastern Tibetan Plateau (NTP), where is strongly affected by mid-latitude westerlies all year round. Moisture originating from the North Atlantic is transported over long distances to the NTP region via the mid-latitude westerlies, and the North Atlantic has been identified as the primary marine oceanic source for atmospheric moisture20 in this region (Fig. S1). Additionally, we investigate the underly physical mechanisms driving glacier mass changes attributable to NASST anomalies. Annual glacier mass change data are obtained from Hugonnet et al.21. Multidecadal estimations of glacier mass balance are derived from digital elevation models (DEMs) generated using topographical maps and ASTER imagery.ResultsInterannual and multidecadal glacier mass balance in the NTPBased on the glacier mass change dataset developed by Hugonnet et al.21 using ASTER images, we observed substantial interannual variability in aggregated glacier mass balance across the NTP from 2000 onwards. Based on detrended time series, annual glacier mass balance from Hugonnet et al.21 showed a strong negative correlation with observed summer temperature (r = −0.70, p < 0.01), but not a significant correlation with annual precipitation (r = 0.14, p > 0.05) over the NTP. Regional temperature and precipitation changes were often modulated by large-scale dynamic processes related to SST anomalies. We regressed global SSTs against NTP glacier mass balance from 2000 to 2019, using detrended observations to remove the background warming signal (see Methods), in order to explore the potential impact of SST anomalies on glacier mass balance variability in the region. A steady and statistically robust signal emerged in the North Atlantic Ocean (Fig. 2, Fig. S3a), whereas responses in the Pacific and Indian Oceans were weak and statistically insignificant during the same period. This spatial pattern was confirmed by the reconstructed mass balance series derived from in-situ observations of two NTP glaciers25 during 2000–2018 (Fig. S4). This signal resembled the interannual variability in NASST modes and showed a tripole pattern (Fig. S3b), which explained 33.6% of the variance in NTP glacier annual mass balance during 2000–2019 (Fig. S3c). Moreover, the dominant NASST modes were seasonally dependent, which gradually weaken from winter to summer and disappear in autumn (Fig. S5). Specially during summer (June-August, JJA), the two leading SST Empirical Orthogonal Function (EOF) modes (accounting for 38.2% variance of NASST) displayed a pronounced tripole pattern with increased strength in the second mode (Fig. 3a, b). During the positive phase of the summer NASST tripole pattern, characterized by a meridional negative-positive-negative (like −+−) SST pattern in the subtropical to subarctic North Atlantic Ocean (Fig. 3a, b), enhanced convective activity over the central North Atlantic induced strong upward motion, leading to the development of anomalous high-pressure ridges developing in the upper troposphere (Fig. 3e, f). The resulting atmospheric Rossby wave train propagated eastward through mid-latitude westerlies, causing an upper-level trough over the Mediterranean and the Central Asian-West Siberian, and an anomalous high-pressure ridge over the Ural Mountains region and the North China plain-northern TP (Fig. 3g). The high-pressure anomaly reduced total cloud cover and enhanced surface solar radiation in the NTP, accompanied by oceanic warm air resulting from the atmospheric teleconnection27,28.Maximum covariance analysis (MCA) (see Methods) revealed that warming in the NTP was associated with an upper-level Rossby wave propagation induced by the interannual NASST anomalies (Fig. S6). MCA further identified an atmospheric fingerprint associated with the NASST patterns (Fig. S7). These analyses reproduced the NASST tripole patterns and linked them to anomalous anticyclone and cyclone over the northern hemisphere mid-latitude, further confirming a quasi-stationary atmospheric wave train driven by NASST variability consistent with the pattern shown in Fig. 3g. The positive phase of SST tripole modes can induce a atmospheric wave train (like +−+−+), leading to more frequent occurrences of anomalous blocking highs over the NTP. Anticyclonic circulation generated strong subsidence and warm southeasterly winds, further amplifying surface warming over the region. Elevated temperature intensified glacier melting. Thus, the positive phase of NASST tripole patterns can trigger an anomalous atmospheric Rossby wave train that exacerbates NTP glacier mass loss through thermal forcing.The NASST tripole pattern can also regulate the NTP glacier mass balance by influencing precipitation changes. This study focused on investigating the role of summer precipitation on glacier changes, because it accounted for 60–80% of annual precipitation, and dominated its inter-annual variability (Fig. S8). The first leading EOF mode (explaining 26.7% of the variability) consisted of a south-north dipole over the TP with negative precipitation anomalies in the south, and positive anomalies in the north, including the NTP (Fig. 4c and Fig. S9a). The northern wetting resulted largely from a weakening of the Eurasian subtropical westerly jet (SWJ) in summer15. At the interannual scale, the summer SWJ was closely associated with the NASST tripole pattern (Fig. 4a, b). The positive phase of the NASST tripole pattern corresponded to a significant weakening of the 200 hPa zonal wind over the TP and a strengthening over the Mongolian Plateau (Fig. 4b). This dipole pattern was linked to a blocking anticyclone over the North China plain and northern TP (Fig. 3g), generated by the interannual NASST-triggered wave train. This atmospheric configuration resulted in anomalous westerly winds on the north side of the anticyclone, and easterly and southeasterly winds on the south side. The latter weakened the SWJ, promoting anomalous vertical moisture advection and hence enhancing precipitation on the NTP. The increased precipitation may be beneficial to snow accumulation over the glaciers and partly mitigate warming-induced melting. Despite the precipitation rise, the snow-to-rain ratio dropped by 13.6% from 1965–1999 to 2000–2020. Sensitivity experiments29 revealed that a 1.5 °C warming over 2000–2010 relative to the 1950s caused 51.9% glacier melting of the Laohugou No. 12 Glacier in this area, which required a 30% enhancement in annual snowfall to offset the resulting mass loss. Sensitivity analysis using an energy and mass balance model for Qiyi and Ningchan No.1 glaciers of this region also showed that almost all mass loss of the two glaciers from 1970–1994 to 1995–2015 resulted from increased summer temperature over the same two timespans24. Thus, the more negative NTP glacier mass balance since 2000 was primarily forced by regional summer warming. Another important factor was warming-induced reduction in precipitation falling as snow24. Given these climatic influences, a critical research priority was to elucidate how atmospheric circulation patterns modulate decadal-scale glacier mass balance variability over the NTP via their influence on temperature and precipitation patterns. On multidecadal scales, the AMO (see Methods) has been recognized as a major driver of climate variability across Eurasia30. Indeed, a strong positive correlation (r = 0.61, p < 0.01) existed between the AMO index and summer air temperature on the NTP glacier region, underscoring the important AMO’s influence on NTP glacier mass budget. Since the mid-1990s, the AMO experienced a multi-decadal shift from a cold to a warm phase (Fig. 5c). During its warm period, warmer SST caused anticyclonic circulation anomalies over the North Atlantic, which propagated a wave train of cyclonic and anticyclonic anomalies across Eurasia31 (Fig.5a), strengthening anticyclonic conditions over the NTP and increasing regional temperatures during 2000–2020. Increased temperature directly enhanced glacier melting and further exacerbated this by reducing snowpack on the glacier surface and corresponding surface albedo. Opposite to the positive polarity of the AMO, the summer SWJ index switched from positive to negative anomalies during the mid-1990s. This switch largely resulted from the AMO-triggered anticyclonic blocking (Fig. 5a) over the Mongolian, which led to easterly anomalies and anomalous upward motion over the NTP (in front of the trough) (Fig. 5b), and caused increased precipitation (Fig. 4d). Moreover, orographic uplift enhanced ascending air motion, which in turn further promoted increased precipitation. However, due to an increase in dedacal summer temperature associated with AMO phase shift and anthropogenic forcing, the mean snow-to-rain ratio over the NTP glaciers decreased from 37.7% (1965–2000) to 24.1% (2000–2020) (Fig. S10). Furthermore, the ratio consistently remained below 0.5 throughout the post-2000 period, indicating a transition toward rainfall-dominated precipitation, which further intensified glacier ablation.DiscussionWe found that the interannual variability of the NTP glacier mass budget was closely associated with the interannual NASST tripole mode. This covariation arose that the mid-latitude westerlies, teleconnected with the extratropical Atlantic ocean climate through atmospheric wave propagation, serve as the predominant boundary conditions driving temporal variability in glacier mass budget over the NTP. In particular, atmospheric waves triggered by the interannual mode of the interannual NASST tripole pattern facilitate the occurrence of anomalous cyclone and anticyclones, and alter the SWJ strength on the NTP during summer. In turn, these changes obviously impacted local temperature and precipitation, thereby resulting in glacier mass variations. Correlation analysis using detrended time series of reconstructed mass balance against temperature and precipitation showed that temperature was the dominant driver of glacier mass loss in this region (Fig. S11), which explained approximately 47% and 60% of mass budget variations of the Qiyi Glacier and the Laohugou No.12 Glacier, respectively. By comparison, precipitation played a minor role in glacier accumulation (in Qiyi Glacier (r = 0.15, p > 0.05) and in Laohugou No.12 Glacier (r = 0.22, p > 0.05). Despite a substantial influence of the East Asian summer monsoon on glacier changes elsewhere on the TP during summer, its impact on glacier changes on the NTP was minor, as more than 95% of the glacierized regions lay outside the boundaries of the summer monsoon on the TP35.Previous studies have recognized a warming and wetting trend since the 1980s, with an acceleration from the mid-1990s onward over Northwest China including the NTP36,37. While much of the overall warming was attributable to ongoing emission of greenhouse gases38, our analyses, based on the detrended and low-frequency-filtered observational and reanalysis data, showed that internal climate variability, especially the NASST tripole pattern and the AMO phase transition, also played a key role. The multi-decadal signatures from AMO dynamics were superimposed onto the interannual variability in NTP glacier mass balance by altering glacier melting and accumulation conditions. Simulations from the Atlantic Pacemaker experiments using CESM1 with external forcings removed exhibited that during the positive phase of the AMO, SST anomalies induced the anomalous anticyclonic circulation (Fig. S12), which propagated toward the TP via the Rossby wave trains. This led to an upper-level anticyclonic high over the NTP (Fig. S13), suppressing cloud formation and reducing surface albedo (Fig. S14), thereby enhancing regional warming, as observed higher average temperatures during 2000–2020 than 1965–2000, which accelerated glacier ablation after 2000. Furthermore, the easterly and southeasterly winds associated with the anticyclone block westerly airflow, resulting in increased precipitation. But because of elevated temperature, a decrease in the average snow-to-rain ratio during 2000–2020 was observed, relative to 1965–2000 (Fig. S10). The increased precipitation falling as rain further enhanced melting. An additional factor contributing to glacier mass loss was the deposition of light-absorbing impurities such as black carbon (BC) on glacier surfaces, which reduced the albedo and caused glacier melting. Yet, they only accounted for about 6.3% of current glacier melting on the NTP39. Therefore, projections of future glacier evolution in this region must account for both anthropogenic forcing and internal modes of climate variability such as the AMO and interannual NASST patterns.ConclusionsThis study highlights the obvious influence of NASST anomalies on glacier mass balance variability over the NTP at both interannual and multidecadal timescales. Over the past 50-plus years, glaciers in the NTP region experienced an acceleration of mass loss, with rates increasing from −0.16 ± 0.14 m w.e. yr−1 (1965–2000) to −0.25 ± 0.10 m w.e. yr−1 (2000–2020). The interannual NASST tripole pattern excited atmospheric wave trains that propagate across Eurasia, driving regional climate anomalies and then year-to-year NTP glacier mass fluctuations. At the multidecadal scale, the AMO’s phase transition from negative to positive since 2000 amplified summer warming which contributed to accelerated glacier mass loss. These findings emphasize natural oceanic variability as a critical modulator of glacier responses to ongoing climate changes in the HMA. Quantifying these linkages is imperative for projecting future glacier dynamics under anthropogenic forcing.Data and MethodsDEM constructionA total of 84 topographic maps at the scale of 1:50000 across the NTP were collected, with contour lines with a 10-meter interval, generated by the Chinese Military Geodetic Service (CMGS) using aerial photogrammetry. After digitizing the scanned topographic map contour lines, the Delaunay triangulation method was used to create irregular triangulation networks, from which historical DEMs (here called TOPO-DEM) were constructed. Aerial photographs used to generate the topographic maps of the NTP glacier region were acquired from 1956 to 1975, with the majority (covering more than 50% glacier area) dating to the mid-1960s (Table S2). Thus, TOPO-DEM was taken to represent the entire NTP glacier surface elevation circa 1965. According to the compilation standards and specifications of the topographic Maps released by the General Administration of Quality Supervision Inspection and Quarantine40, the vertical error of topographic maps were controlled within 6–10 m for the flat or hilly regions with slopes less than 6°, 10–16 m in mountainous areas with slopes of 6°–25°, and 16–28 m in high mountain areas with slopes greater than 25°, respectively. With an average slope of 17.8° across the NTP glacier region, the TOPO-DEM vertical accuracy was estimated to be better than ±8 m.For contemporary glacier elevation, we acquired all available AST_L1A stereo imageries (30 m resolution) covering the NTP glaciers for the 2000–2002 and 2019–2021 epochs. Using the NASA Ames Stereo Pipeline (ASP) tool, DEMs were created from the AST_L1A stereo images (3 N band and 3B band). We manually selected the high-quality and minimal-void data and mosaicked them to generate glacier surface DEMs for 2000 and 2020, respectively. The SRTM Version 3.0 Global 1 arc second dataset (SRTM GL1) served as a vertical reference. All DEMs were harmonized to the World Geodetic System 1984 (WGS84) coordinate system and EGM96 vertical datum.Glacier extent extractionGlacier boundaries for the NTP in 1965 were digitized directly from topographic maps. Landsat 7 Enhanced Thematic Mapper Plus (ETM + ) and Landsat 8 Operational Land Imager/Thermal Infrared Sensor (OLI/TIRS) images with cloud cover less than 10%, acquired during June–October, were used to manually delineate the glacier outlines in 2000 and 2020, respectively. A total of 30 Landsat 7 ETM+ images and 26 Landsat 8 OLI_TIRS images were used (Table S3). All images were reprojected to the WGS84 geographic coordinate system and the Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) projection. Co-registration with topographic maps was performed using 20–30 ground control points (GCPs), ensuring registration errors within one pixel. To enhance ice-rock spectral contrast, false-color composites were generated using Shortwave Infrared-2 (band 7), Near-Infrared (band 5), and Green (band 3) wavelengths. Glacier boundaries were then manually digitized through visual interpretation, cross-validated with the Randolph Glacier Inventory v6.0 (RGI 6.0).Glacier mass balance changes and uncertaintiesPrior to glacier surface elevation and mass balance calculations, the Nuth and Kääb co-registration method41 was used to estimate DEM misalignments and correct spatial offsets between the multi-source DEMs. This approach iteratively solved a cosine equation to estimate the direction and magnitude of displacement, based on a Python package xDEM42. Iterations terminated when either the maximum number of steps was reached or the normalized median absolute deviation (NMAD) no longer improved obviously. After differencing DEMs (dDEM) to obtain surface elevation changes, we filtered out the eliminated values with elevation changes of more than 100 m or slopes of greater than 45° to minimize noise. Then, the remaining voids in the dDEM were filled by a regional hypsometric interpolation method (integrated in the xDEM package), which assumed that elevation changes were strongly dependent on elevation and estimated elevation change gradients across the region to interpolate missing data. Ultimately, we combined the different DEMs and a snow-ice density conversion factor (\(\rho\)) (850 ± 60 kg m−3)43 to estimate the decadal glacier mass balance in the NTP region during 1965–2020. Its spatial pattern resembled the first EOF pattern of the NASST, characterized by dominant warming in the North Atlantic and a bi-center structure near southern Greenland and the tropical Atlantic Ocean. Following previous studies15,32, the subtropical westerly jet (SWJ) was defined as the averaged zonal wind over 35°–45°N, 40°-120°E.Correlation, regression, EOF, and MCAPearson correlation coefficients were calculated after removing long-term trends from the datasets. Two-tailed Student’s t-test was applied to calculate the statistical significance of all regressions and correlations. Additionally, to further verify how NASST affects temperature and precipitation variations as well as glacial mass balance in the NTP region by influencing atmospheric circulation anomalies, we analyzed summer-mean horizontal wind fields, geopotential height fields, vertical velocity, water vapor flux, snow-to-rain ratio, and albedo differences/anomalies for the 1965–2000 and 2000–2020 periods. All variables were derived from the ERA5 reanalysis, with the exception of snowfall and rainfall, which were sourced from the ERA5-Land dataset.Empirical orthogonal function (EOF) analysis was applied to extract the meridional tripole structure of the North Atlantic (0°–70°N, 90°W–15°E) SST variability during 1965–2020, with positive (negative) loadings in the south of Greenland and the subtropics, and negative (positive) loadings in between (Fig. 3a, b; Fig. S5). items.title: Consiglio UE: obiettivo climatico ulteriormente rinviato
items.description:
I leader europei si sono riuniti ieri per discutere l'obiettivo climatico dell'UE per il 2040, ma non hanno raggiunto una decisione
The post Consiglio
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Appello WWF ai ministri europei I leader europei si sono riuniti ieri per discutere l’obiettivo climatico dell’UE per il 2040, ma non hanno raggiunto una decisione e hanno ripassato il testimone ai ministri dell’Ambiente, che a loro volta glielo avevano passato circa un mese fa. Hanno però messo in chiaro un dato fondamentale: l’obiettivo di riduzione delle emissioni del 90% è ancora l’unico sul tavolo. Il WWF esorta i ministri dell’Ambiente dell’Unione europea a portare a termine il lavoro in tempo per la COP30 a Belém, confermando l’obiettivo per il 2040 di almeno il 90% di riduzione delle emissioni, senza alcuna compensazione internazionale.Dopo il vertice di ieri, manca quindi solo una tappa prima di Belém: la prevista riunione straordinaria del Consiglio dei ministri dell’Ambiente dell’Unione europea il 4 novembre. A novembre in Brasile la COP 30 Il 6 e 7 novembre prossimi, a Belem in Brasile, si terrà il Leaders’ Summit e poi si aprirà la COP30 dal 10 al 21 novembre. Il Consiglio Ambiente, quindi, sarà l’ultima possibilità dell’Europa prima della COP30 e l’ultima opportunità per concordare un obiettivo credibile di riduzione delle emissioni per il 2035, richiesto dall’Accordo di Parigi come parte del contributo nazionale determinato (NDC) dell’Unione Europea. Tale obiettivo non è stato ancora presentato proprio a causa del ritardo nel concordare l’obiettivo per il 2040. “I ministri dell’Ambiente hanno passato il testimone ai leader europei, che lo hanno restituito immediatamente. È ora di smetterla con questo gioco allo scaricabarile. Occorre prendere una decisione, affinché l’Unione non si presenti alla COP30 di Belém a mani vuote”, ha affermato Mariagrazia Midulla, responsabile Clima ed Energia del WWF Italia. Nel testo delle conclusioni del Consiglio permangono insidie sui tempi, sull’ammontare e sulla qualità delle compensazioni internazionali, che potrebbero indebolire l’ambizione complessiva dell’obiettivo. “L’obiettivo del 90% non è stato contestato dai leader dell’Unione, quindi rimane l’unico numero sul tavolo. La domanda è: quanto di questo sarà costituito da reali riduzioni delle emissioni interne, piuttosto che da compensazioni internazionali? Considerando quanto queste si siano dimostrate inaffidabili in passato, la risposta giusta deve essere zero. Potrebbero sembrare buone sulla carta, ma il clima non può essere ingannato da una contabilità creativa. L’Italia insiste molto sui crediti internazionali, preferendo investire all’estero che in una giusta transizione a livello nazionale: quando si dice la mancanza di coerenza”, ha aggiunto Midulla.Mentre la sveglia climatica suona sempre più forte, l’Europa non può più permettersi di rimandare la questione. Le decisioni che i Ministri dell’Ambiente prenderanno il 4 novembre determineranno se l’Unione europea arriverà alla COP30 da leader o da fanalino di coda in materia di clima. E al momento attuale l’Europa non può assolutamente permettersi di perdere autorevolezza. Spinta alla deregolamentazione I leader dell’Unione europea hanno anche rinnovato la loro spinta alla “semplificazione” delle leggi dell’Unione, una mossa che rischia di indebolire le protezioni ambientali fondamentali. Da quando è entrata in carica, la spinta alla semplificazione della Commissione europea si è tradotta in una vera e propria deregolamentazione che ha già portato a un indebolimento di diversi standard ambientali e sanitari. Ieri i leader hanno chiesto una deregolamentazione ancora più ampia, sulla scia di una lettera congiunta di 19 capi di Stato e di governo, tra cui l’Italia, che sollecitano un “flusso costante” di proposte omnibus deregolatorie da parte della Commissione. Questa azione della Commissione si è contraddistinta per la mancanza di trasparenza, di adeguate valutazioni d’impatto e di consultazione pubblica, e sono attualmente oggetto di indagine da parte dell’Ombudsman europeo. Dante Caserta, Responsabile Affari legali e istituzionali del WWF Italia, ha dichiarato: “Dalle conclusioni di ieri vediamo scarse garanzie che i leader dell’Unione europea vogliano davvero proteggere le norme a tutela delle persone e della natura. Se hanno davvero a cuore la competitività e la certezza normativa per le imprese, dovrebbero attuare pienamente le leggi ambientali esistenti: in questo modo farebbero risparmiare all’economia dell’Unione almeno 180 miliardi di euro all’anno secondo una ricerca della stessa Commissione, rispetto agli appena 8 miliardi di euro previsti dalla deregolamentazione”.
